docs.lead_paragraph: The Congressional Budget Office has released a revised cost analysis of the health care bill that the Senate adopted Dec. 24, putting the price tag at about $875 billion over 10 years, an increase of about $4 billion from the previous estimate. Because the cost would be more than offset by revenues from proposed new taxes and reductions in government spending, the budget office predicted that the bill over all would reduce future federal deficits by $118 billion over 10 years. In its earlier estimate, the budget office said the bill would reduce future deficits by $132 billion.
docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office's revised cost analysis of Senate's health care bill puts price tag at about $875 billion over 10 years, increase of about $4 billion from previous estimate (M)
docs.snippet: The Congressional Budget Office has released a revised cost analysis of the health care bill that the Senate adopted Dec. 24, putting the price tag at about $875 billion over 10 years, an increase of about $4 billion from the previous estimate.     ...

docs.lead_paragraph: In an 11th-hour barrage, each side in the health care debate is pouring millions of dollars into television advertisements before Congress votes on a bill, which it is scheduled to do late next week. The advertisements include one from Americans for Prosperity, a conservative group that opposes the bill. The advertisement, which is running in 18 Congressional districts and costs $750,000, features a woman who says a federal panel's new guidelines on delaying mammograms would have left her cancer undetected.
docs.abstract: Each side in health care debate is pouring millions of dollars into TV advertisements before Congress votes on bill; air wars over health care have already steered more than $200 million to local broadcast and cable outlets, making issue most expensive single advocacy campaign in single year; most of money has been spent in opposition to Democratic effort to alter health care system (M)
docs.snippet: In an 11th-hour barrage, each side in the health care debate is pouring millions of dollars into television advertisements before Congress votes on a bill, which it is scheduled to do late next week.     The advertisements include one from Americans...

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps inspired by my criticisms of Paul Ryan's proposed tax reforms, Jonathan Chait has a long post about how Ryan's roadmap "clarifies the essence of the Republican Party's approach to domestic policy issues," which involves "opposition to the downward redistribution of income." Noting that Ryan has said kind words about Ayn Rand, he writes that "the core of the Randian worldview, as absorbed by the modern GOP, is a belief that the natural market distribution of income is inherently moral, and the central struggle of politics is to free the successful from having the fruits of their superiority redistributed by looters and moochers." And he argues: "Every major element of Ryan's plan reflects this commitment ...  Ryan would retain some bare-bones subsidies for the poorest, but the overwhelming thrust in every way is to liberate the lucky and successful to enjoy their good fortune without burdening them with any responsibility for the welfare of their fellow citizens."
docs.abstract: How the Ryan roadmap takes from the rich and gives to the poor.
docs.snippet: How the Ryan roadmap takes from the rich and gives to the poor.

docs.lead_paragraph: According to the National Catholic Reporter, Catholics in Alliance for the Common Good, a Washington-based advocacy group, sent a letter to members of Congress on Friday urging support for the Senate-passed health care bill and expressing its view that the bill contains sufficient provisions to prevent the use of federal money to pay for insurance coverage of abortions.

headline.main: Senate Abortion Restrictions Are Sufficient, Catholic Group Says

docs.abstract: A Catholic advocacy group says it is satisfied by the abortion restrictions in the Senate bill.
docs.snippet: A Catholic advocacy group says it is satisfied by the abortion restrictions in the Senate bill.
